(b) If not, why?

LANDS BELONGING TO EHETUWEWA DS DIVISION,
() , ? ask the Minister of Wildlife and Forest Resources Conservation :

(i) environmentalists have pointed out that there is a plan to lease out to businessmen some extent of land in Nakolagane Grama Niladhari Division and some other Divisions in Ehetuwewa Divisional Secretary's Division in Kurunegala District, stating that the said land is the fief belonging to Nakolagane Rajamaha Temple;
(ii) about 20 per cent of Sri Lanka's wild elephant population lives in the above-mentioned area; and
(iii) the elephant-human conflict in the above area may further escalate due to the lease of the said land?
(b) Will she inform this House of the action that will be taken regarding the above lease?
(c) If not, why? ( () ) (The Hon. (Mrs.) Pavithradevi Wanniarachchi, Attorney-at-Law) , .

BUDDHIST TEMPLES IN MANNAR DISTRICT: DEVELOPMENT
() , ? asked the Minister of Buddhasasana, Religious and Cultural Affairs:

(a) Will he inform this House - (i) the number of Buddhist temples found in Mannar District; (ii) whether the temples in rural areas of the said district with many shortcomings have been identified; (iii) if so, what those temples are; and (iv) whether steps have been taken to develop those temples?

(b) Will he also inform this House - (i) whether the temples with archaeological value, out of the said temples, have been identified; and (ii) the programme implemented by now to conserve those temples?

PRESIDENT (, , ) ( - , ) (The Hon. Ranil Wickremesinghe - President, Minister of Defence and Minister of Finance, Economic Stabilization and National Policies) , 12 , , IMF . It states, I quote:

Sri Lankas agreements-in-principle with the Official Creditors Committee and Export-Import Bank of China on debt treatments are consistent with the EFF targets. They are an important milestone putting Sri Lankas debt on the path towards sustainability. A swift completion and signature of the Memoranda of Understanding with the official creditors is important. Timely implementation of the agreements, together with reaching a resolution with external private creditors on comparable terms, should help restore Sri Lankas debt sustainability over the medium term.

They have now announced that Sri Lanka has reached debt sustainability. We have already done our negotiations with the bilateral creditors and now, we are left only to do it with the private creditors and international sovereign bondholders. Nevertheless, under this, we will now be dealing with foreign governments and getting the suspended aid restored.

( ) (The Hon. Shehan Semasinghe) Hon. Leader of the Opposition, once again, I request you to read this IMF Press Release. This clearly states how the economy is functioning and what steps we have to take. So, without reading and understanding this, I think you should not make a fool of yourself.

( ) (The Hon. Sajith Premadasa) Hon. Chairman, - ( ) (The Hon. Chairman) . ( ) (The Hon. Sajith Premadasa) With respect, Hon. State Minister, I must say that I have gone through all the specific details, the nuances, the intricacies and the specific details of all the announcements made and I want to assure you that I have the necessary reading skills to do so. I have comprehended the fact that the Government has not entered into a good deal for the people. We agree with an IMF deal, but we have to enter into a deal on behalf of the people, not on behalf of the rich people or the people who earn supernormal profits.

( ) (The Hon. Shehan Semasinghe) Hon. Leader of the Opposition, what I raised was, your speech did not reflect the points in the IMF Press Release. That shows your ignorance or that you have not understood what is in that Press Release. That is the point I was trying to make.
( ) (The Hon. Sajith Premadasa) Sir, I rise to a point of Order. ( ) (The Hon. Chairman) , .

( ) (The Hon. Sajith Premadasa) Hon. Chairman, I am not here to prepare my speech based on IMF statements. I have a mind of my own; I have an intellect of my own and I have the capacity and the knowledge to understand economic principles and policies. I do not need IMF statements to base my speeches on.

. . ( . ) (The Hon. Premnath C. Dolawatte, Attorney-at-Law) Hon. Chairman, when there is a crisis, you can identify clearly who the leaders are. So, at this juncture, I think I must salute the Government and the President, who have been making tremendous efforts towards obtaining the second tranche of the IMF loan during this crisis. I have heard that Santa Claus is in town, but I have not seen Santa Claus in Parliament. Anyway, now, you can experience having Santa Claus in Parliament. Actually, if I have more time to reply to the Leader of the Opposition, I would be delighted, but I do not.

Sir, I am really concerned about Item 10 in todays Order Paper of Parliament and would like to brief you on that. Sir, I stand before you today to address a matter of utmost importance: the rights and the protection of the LGBTQ plus community in our beloved nation, Sri Lanka.

( ) (The Hon. Sajith Premadasa) It is LGBTQI, not LGBTQ plus. . . ( . ) (The Hon. Premnath C. Dolawatte, Attorney-at-Law) Yes, whatever. - [Interruption.] Please, do not disturb me. I did not disturb you. I have been given only a minimum time, five minutes. Hon. Leader of the Opposition, you have been standing up again and again, taking all our time. What is this? Also, like you, I am not that much of an expert in English. So, please do not disturb.

Sir, with that Item, I hope to present to this House a vital Amendment to the principal enactment or the Penal Code aimed at amending Sections 365 and 365A, which criminalizes same-sex sexual activities. This Amendment Bill was presented to Parliament for its First Reading in 2022 by me, which seeks to protect the fundamental rights of individuals regardless of their sexual orientation and to foster a society that upholds equality and justice for all. The Sri Lankan society has, unfortunately, been plagued by deeply-regressive and backward attitudes towards the LGBTQ plus community. Societal prejudice and discrimination against individuals based on their sexual orientation or gender identity have been pervasive. Not only in their daily life, but also within government institutions and law enforcement agencies, this community has been subjected to various forms of violence, harassment and oppression, preventing them from enjoying the same rights and freedom the others in our society have taken for granted.

. . ( . ) (The Hon. Premnath C. Dolawatte, Attorney-at-Law) Sir, if I am unable to finish within my five minutes, I will take two more minutes. The Hon. Sahan Pradeep Withana will grant me two minutes from his allotted time.

It is our duty, as elected Representatives, to acknowledge and address those injustices. We cannot turn a blind eye to the sufferings of our fellow citizens who have been marginalized and discriminated against for far too long. So, the time has come for us to take a stand and bring meaningful changes to the laws, which would protect and empower the LGBTQ plus community.

Across the globe, many developed countries have taken significant steps to amend the laws which penalized individuals based on their sexual orientation or gender identity. They have recognized the inherent rights of all individuals to live freely and without fear or persecution due to who they are and who they love. Therefore, it is time for us also, as the people of Sri Lanka, to follow suit and speak out in defence of their fundamental rights.

By amending the Penal Code and decriminalizing the same-sex sexual activities, we can pave the way for a more inclusive and just society. This Amendment is not just a legal technicality, but also a statement of our commitment to human rights and equality; it is an affirmation that every individual, regardless of their sexual orientation and gender identity, deserves to be treated with dignity and respect under the law. In addition to amending the Penal Code, we must also take concrete steps to address the societal attitudes that perpetuate discrimination or prejudice against the LGBTQ plus community. Hon. Leader of the Opposition, "plus" means whatever other identifications that would be made next under this category. That is why I used the term "LGBTQ plus".

Education and awareness campaigns are essential to fostering a culture of acceptance and understanding. Furthermore, we must ensure that legal protection is in place to safeguard the rights of the LGBTQ plus individuals in all aspects of life including employment, healthcare and housing. As we move forward, let us remember that protection of human rights knows no boundaries. We must stand fast alongside human rights defenders and advocates who are working tirelessly to ensure that the LGBTQ plus community is afforded the same rights and opportunities the other members of the society enjoy. Let us be the voice of change and progress, striving to create a Sri Lanka where everyone could live with equal rights and without fear of discrimination of future generations to come. I think the entire House would agree on this and support this. The Second Reading of this Bill will be moved in this House in the meantime.

( ) (The Hon. Presiding Member) Next, the Hon. Rauff Hakeem. You have five minutes. [2.16 p.m.] ( ) (The Hon. Rauff Hakeem, Attorney-at-Law) Bismillahir Rahmanir Raheem.

Hon. Presiding Member, the Hon. President came to this House in the morning and announced the grant of the second tranche by the IMF in our debt restructuring process. And, he himself admitted that though the second tranche is being released, it is only a limited victory in a long journey, which will have other serious issues to be addressed as well. According to the President, the next step would be to renegotiate with the private creditors, which is also quite a challenging task. In the meantime, it is his contention that the contraction of the economy is a serious challenge we are faced with at the moment.

Now, the contracting economy has caused a serious breakdown in a variety of business spheres in the country, not to mention the agriculture. If you go by the Y ala and Maha seasons and the harvest that we have been managing to produce, we see that there is a sharp drop and that this trend is going to continue. What is connected with this is, the climate vulnerabilities in the country. Climate-related disasters is a serious problem that our country very frequently faces, as we are a country close to the equator. Being a very tropical country, we are now faced with very frequent climate-related disasters.

If you take flooding, the recent flooding in the Akurana area is a phenomenon that we see happening very frequently. If we take the flooding of the Pinga-Oya which flows through the Akurana Town towards Katugastota and merges with the Mahaweli River, there was an assumption that the erection of the Polgolla Dam is what is causing all these issues and that the sand silting collected at the place where the Oya merges with the Mahaweli River has got its flow affected due to the Polgolla Dam. The fact is, we had had several attempts made to solve this issue. There had been an inter-

ministerial committee chaired by a Senior Assistant Secretary of my own Ministry and we also appointed a task force to go into the reasons for flooding of the Pinga-Oya across the Akurana Town very frequently. Four months ago, at the meeting held in the Akurana Divisional Secretariat, I raised the issue and asked the Divisional Secretary and the officials of the UDA who had come there as to whether any action has been taken about the unauthorized structures which had to be demolished according to the report that was submitted. So, follow-up action is what is lacking together with various other connected improvements that we have to make along the Pinga-Oya flow. From about the eighth or the ninth mile post up to the Ambatale Junction, there have been a variety of issues which need to be resolved. This needs both certain legal actions by authorities like the Urban Development Authority, which had been quite lacking in its approach to taking those actions, and also a civil society responsibility to engage with those agencies to see that it is expedited. So, this matter, though we had raised it several times and only four months ago I raised it at the District Development Committee meeting, too, is still pending. Therefore, I, in fact, brought it up here since it is the President who is the Minister of Finance and his Vote is being debated today. I made a request from the President to allow us to have a meeting with him in Kandy when he visits Kandy this Sunday to participate in the District Development Committee meeting. He has assured both the Hon. Abdul Haleem and myself representing the Kandy District and other civil society representatives that after the District Development Committee meeting, we could meet him along with the officials of the UDA and other government agencies - the Department of Irrigation, the Disaster Management Centre and the Road Development Authority - who are to be summoned to discuss this matter. With that meeting, I hope we could take some effective action and the State agencies which are entrusted with the responsibility to carry out the necessary corrective work must do their work so that such disasters do not happen repeatedly all the time. I thank the Hon. President for having allowed us some time to meet him and discuss this issue.

Also, I want to refer to the Climate Resilience Improvement Project - CRIP. There must be some way in which the CRIP gets involved in this. I think that is a rolling project which has to be given more funding so that this type of frequent climate-related issues could be addressed effectively. Thank you.
( ) (The Hon. Presiding Member) Next, the Hon. Sivagnanam Shritharan. You have six minutes.

average age 30 . 40 . , . -financial literacy - . . If there is an aging population, it would be even more difficult to get financial literacy improved. The more we delay, the bigger the chance would be of us falling into a greater depth of the financial crisis.

, . . . , because Sri Lanka has been able to qualify for the next tranche of about US Dollars 330 million of the IMF Extended Fund Facility after much commitment, effort and winning clear international financial confidence. Obviously, that effort has not been short of targets which were hard to achieve. In financial language, we call it a "straitjacket" that we have to wear. A straitjacket leaves no space or freedom to move around. Therefore, it has been achieved with great difficulty. However, it has brought about the much-needed confidence and stability in our country. The growth was on a negative curve and we are now stepping into a positive curve. We must turn this for the betterment of each and every citizen of the country. So, my final appeal is that we collectively look at bringing in a comprehensive new look to our economy in the future. I thank you, Sir, for the time allotted.

[4.14 p.m.] ( ) (The Hon. Eran Wickramaratne) Hon. Presiding Member, today, we are not talking about Walter's Disneyland; we are talking about Ranil's Disneyland. We need to have a bit of a reality check on this. I believe in transparency and accountability. The Budget Proposals cannot only be in the entertainment block. . , , . , . .
, Budget Proposals , - National Centre for Artificial Intelligence - . 3 . , , . . 2017 12. 2023 97 .
tax . . , defence spending, welfare spending . . , . , . . , . , . . . If I were to borrow a few principles to be adopted by the Budget Office, we should look at development and execution.
( ) (The Hon. Presiding Member) Hon. Member, please wind up. Your time is over. ( ) (The Hon. Eran Wickramaratne) I am finishing up, Sir.

Then, management, including oversight of the performance of agencies and a lot of other things need to be looked at. For example, procurement, financial management, information technology, coordination, review of all significant regulations and privacy and information policy. Then, we also have to look at how we are going to monitor whether they are implemented or not.

Finally, I would say that this is a Disneyland dream and I call that Disneyland Ranil Disneyland. I am telling the officials, you should make sure that these Proposals could actually be implemented because on the face of it, it looks like that a lot of these targets cannot be achieved. Therefore, allocate resources necessary for evaluation and monitoring.
Thank you for giving me time, Sir.

The authorities have made commendable progress toward restoring debt sustainability, raising revenue, rebuilding reserves buffers, reducing inflation, and safeguarding financial stability....
...Strong commitment to improving governance and protecting the poor and vulnerable remains critical.
Macroeconomic policy reforms are starting to bear fruit and the economy is showing tentative signs of stabilization,....
.....with rapid disinflation, significant revenue-based fiscal adjustment, and reserves build-up.
Sri Lankas agreements-in-principle with the Official Creditors Committee and Export-Import Bank of China on debt treatments are consistent with the EFF targets...

They are an important milestone putting Sri Lankas debt on the path towards sustainability. A swift completion and signature of the Memoranda of Understanding with the official creditors is important. Timely implementation of the agreements, together with reaching a resolution with external private creditors on comparable terms, should help restore Sri Lankas debt sustainability over the medium term.

First Schedule, as amended, ordered to stand part of the Bill.

Bill accordingly read a Second time, and allocated by THE HON. SPEAKER to Legislative Standing Committee under Standing Order 53(3).
It being past 6.00 p.m., THE HON. SPEAKER adjourned Parliament without Question put.
Parliament adjourned accordingly at 7.01 p.m. until 9.30 a.m. on Tuesday. 09th January, 2024, pursuant to the Resolution of Parliament of this Day.
